title: 104_s1857
content: The "Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996" establishes the Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices with duties outlined for the Commission. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996, is tasked with studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will consider the amount of money spent on campaigns, disclosure of funds, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates, and the financing system for campaigns. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996, is studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will assess the disclosure of funds, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates, the financing system for campaigns, and access to media for informing the electorate about candidates' positions on issues. The Bipartisan Commission on Campaign Practices, established by the Bipartisan Campaign Practices Commission Act of 1996, is studying laws and regulations affecting Federal campaign practices. It will assess the disclosure of funds, the impact of current laws on qualified candidates, the financing system for campaigns, and access to media for informing the electorate about candidates' positions on issues. The Commission will also evaluate whether the existing campaign financing system promotes trust and confidence among voters, ensures access to media for candidate information, and address any other relevant matters. SEC. 4. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 9 private sector members appointed by various officials, with a chairperson selected within 7 days. The Commission consists of 9 private sector members appointed by officials, with a chairperson selected within 7 days by majority vote. If the chairperson is not selected within 30 days, the position remains vacant. If the chairperson of the Commission is not selected within 30 days, all current members will be discharged. Vacancies in the Commission will be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members are entitled to receive compensation based on the annual rate of basic pay. The Commission members will be discharged if the chairperson is not selected within 30 days. Vacancies will be filled as per the original appointment process. Each member is entitled to compensation based on the annual rate of basic pay. Six members constitute a quorum, and decisions require the affirmative vote of 6 members. The Commission members are entitled to compensation at the Executive Schedule level V for each day of duty. Six members form a quorum, and decisions require the affirmative vote of 6 members. Meetings are called by the chairperson or at the request of 6 members. The chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint necessary staff without following standard appointment procedures. Additionally, fast track procedures are in place for recommendations. The Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted. The report may include recommendations for changes in laws governing Federal campaigns, agreed upon by 6 or more members. If 7 or more members agree on changes in campaign conduct, they can prepare bills for submission. The Federal Election Commission must submit a report to Congress within 30 days of the 105th Congress convening, detailing the study conducted and any recommended changes in laws governing Federal campaigns. If 7 or more members agree on changes in campaign conduct, they can prepare bills for submission with expedited consideration by Congress. The Commission will end 30 days after submitting the report. $750,000 is authorized for this Act.
